subject: Remove Redfish Node class
commitMessage:
Remove Redfish Node class

Reduces the total number of lines and will allow for easier testing of
the redfish responses.

A main purpose of the node class was to set app.routeDynamic(). However
now app.routeDynamic can handle the complexity that was once in critical
to node. The macro app.routeDynamic() provides a shorter cleaner
interface to the unerlying app.routeDyanic call. The old pattern set
permissions for 6 interfaces (get, head, patch, put, delete_, and post)
even if only one interface is created. That pattern creates unneeded
code that can be safely removed with no effect.
Unit test for the responses would have to mock the node the class in
order to fully test responses.

see https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/issues/181

The following files still need node to be extracted.

virtual_media.hpp
account_service.hpp
redfish_sessions.hpp
ethernet.hpp

The files above use a pattern that is not trivial to address. Often their
responses call an async lambda capturing the inherited class. ie
(https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/ffed87b5ad1797ca966d030e7f979770
28d258fa/redfish-core/lib/account_service.hpp#L1393)
At a later point I plan to remove node from the files above.

Tested:
I ran the docker unit test with the following command.
WORKSPACE=$(pwd) UNIT_TEST_PKG=bmcweb
 ./openbmc-build-scripts/run-unit-test-docker.sh

I ran the validator and this change did not create any issues.
python3 RedfishServiceValidator.py -c config.ini

Signed-off-by: John Edward Broadbent <jebr@google.com>
Signed-off-by: Ed Tanous <edtanous@google.com>
Change-Id: I147a0289c52cb4198345b1ad9bfe6fdddf57f3df

> Gunnar, Does this work for you?

Yes, I am good but do have some concerns: 
1. This is a huge change. +7908 -9165. That is huge. Ideally this would be smaller changes. 
2. This is a directional change, can we get something out to the mailing list or discord? I know the issue has been out there for a long time, but would be good to get more attention to this.
3. There is a lot of changes up for review in bmcweb, this conflicts with a ton of them. I do feel for the authors of those changes.

> > (1 comment)

> > LGTM.
> > 
> > Gunnar, Does this work for you?
> 
> Yes, I am good but do have some concerns: 
> 1. This is a huge change. +7908 -9165. That is huge. Ideally this would be smaller changes. 

How would you like to see it?  Technically each file could independently be it's own commit, but that seemed like more overhead to review when John and I talked about it.

> 2. This is a directional change, can we get something out to the mailing list or discord? I know the issue has been out there for a long time, but would be good to get more attention to this.

John, can you send a mail to the list?  It doesn't have to be long, and the bulk of it can be "FYI, we're implementing this github issue, which will effect all redfish nodes", here's how things will change.

> 3. There is a lot of changes up for review in bmcweb, this conflicts with a ton of them. I do feel for the authors of those changes.

I'm not sure what to do about that in this case;  We could wait longer, but we seem to be accumulating more patches in review, not less, and I'd like to get the binary size wins that this patchset has, as well as the reduced code to review, which should reduce a lot more once the node class is totally gone.

In a perfect world, the authors of the patches that have conflicts would comment on this patch or the github issue and we could discuss how to roll this out in a way that doesn't impact them as much, but that might be too much to expect.

I ran the red fish validator, and this change does not create any issue.
Not sure if it's worth mentioning.....  because I still think this patchset is good as is, but we should probably group up these methods where appropriate.

The pound defines in redfish-core/include/redfish.hpp make it easy to remove features with a high degree of granularity. Grouping features together would make this more difficult.
But I agree some more coarse grouping would help with organization.
This looks wrong.  Should be patch.

typo.

For what it's worth, see what i did with the hypervisor one.  This is just a bad pattern in those files, and the "this" capture doesn't actually get used for any per-member data.  The class methods can be simply moved to normal methods.
Considering you've done the bulk of the work, and even without complete removal of the Node class, this is already better in terms of binary size, I think this is ok for the time being.

Actually see this quite a few places

I didn't think about that..... good point, although technically this is no worse, because we were missing the App include before, and pulling it through the Node header which isn't great from an "include what you use" perspective.
I added the app.hpp as an include to all the responses.
Why declared twice?

Done, It looks like a copy paste issue.
Removed
I found that there is code to check parameters in some methods, but not in other methods. Do we need this check? Should all methods with parameters add or delete this code?

In a perfect world, we should be using sdbusplus::message::object_path along with operator/ to build the path, then checking that for empty()

With that said, the router will never hand you an empty param (<str> is defined as 1 character or more) so it's not an issue in practice that needs to be checked.
Shouldn't this be ConfigureComponents?

Yep;  I'm seeing this has issues in a lot of places.

John, 
Can you please double check that all of these in your new patch matches the old behavior?  (and ideally matches the base privilege registry, but that's optional).

Sounds good. I will review all the privileges, to see is this issue is anywhere else.
What is the privilege registry

> What is the privilege registry

Privilege registry is what defines what these permissions should be.

I corrected this permissions issue across the change.
This should be good to go. Let me know if there are any more concerns.

What about making the handlers free functions to reduce indentation and improve debuggability?
Just a thought, it's up to the maintainers
That's the eventual plan (and a big part of why we're going this direction), but this patchset was already giant and so it needs to be done in stages.

I think independent functions would be great escpally for the really long lambdas. It would also make easier to read and test.

But one step at a time
